title: Worldwise: Real Estate Exec and Arts Patron Jessica Goldman Srebnick’s Favorite Things
text:
Text size

Goldman Properties CEO and arts patron Jessica Goldman Srebnick caught the entrepreneurial bug early, when, around age 12, she began working as a cashier and a coat check attendant in her family’s restaurants.

The daughter of real estate mogul and restaurateur Tony Goldman, Goldman Srebnick grew up in Manhattan with an insider’s view of the business of neighborhood revitalization, in which her father played a key role in the late 1970s and ’80s. At the time, the industrial sector had abandoned SoHo and the neighborhood’s commercial lofts were turning over into work/live spaces for poor artists.

This gritty version of SoHo—which would be unrecognizable to the shoppers who flock to its posh boutiques today—was where Goldman Srebnick and her brother grew up and began working in their father’s restaurants; first Greene Street Café, a garbage-truck garage their father turned into a jazz supper club, and later, Soho Kitchen and Bar, which he launched out of a former metal-cabinet factory.

Goldman, who died in 2012, began buying up buildings in Miami’s neglected Wynwood area in the ’80s, planting the seeds for what would grow into the sprawling, colorful Wynwood Walls arts district that now draws millions of Instagramming visitors each year. With Goldman Srebnick now at the helm, the walls will celebrate their 10th anniversary in December with the release of a retrospective photo book and a slate of events at Art Basel in Miami.

Goldman Srebnick, 49, officially entered the family business at age 27, after spending her post-college years as an associate fashion director at Saks Fifth Avenue. Goldman named her CEO in 2012, shortly before his death. Today, Goldman Srebnick oversees a diverse portfolio of restaurants, office buildings, a boutique hotel, commercial and retail properties, and large-scale public art projects including the Wynwood Walls and the iconic Houston Bowery wall in New York.

“I feel really privileged that I get to do that because it keeps me close to my dad, and it’s a great reminder of what our family legacy is and what I wish for it to continue to be,” she said.

Goldman Srebnick works alongside her brother, Joey Goldman, a partner, and their mother, Janet Goldman, who serves as chairwoman and principal of the company.

In 2015, she founded Goldman Global Arts, a Miami- and New York-based creative collective with co-founder and artist Peter Tunney.

When she’s not vetting new commercial tenants or scoping out the next talented artist to grace the walls, Goldman Srebnick can be found hanging out at home in Miami with her husband, Scott, and their three sons, ages 12, 14, and 16. During some rare downtime, she jumped on the phone with Penta to talk about how she stays current on leadership strategies and how her father’s life lessons stick with her.

My favorite neighborhood in the world is… Wynwood, Miami. It’s by far the most artistic neighborhood in the country and the more I travel, the more I realize how special it is. It’s literally an open-air museum of the streets with the greatest concentration of street art in the world. For me what’s more exciting is that there’s still so much more growth and opportunity ahead for Wynwood. It’s definitely a neighborhood that everyone should be watching, visiting, and participating in.

The one thing in my kitchen I can’t live without is… my juicer, because I’m addicted to watermelon juice. It’s the best thing ever. Sometimes, I add a little mint. It’s an anytime staple. And I can’t get it all the time, because it’s not always watermelon season, so when it is in season, I’m all about it.

The best book I’ve read in the last year is… I read Harvard Business School case studies on lots of different topics—leading in times of crisis, differentiating yourself in business, best practices in hiring, for example. The world is changing all the time, and it’s important to be current in how you’re creating culture in an organization or best practices with human resources, or understanding how technology affects growth.

If I were to buy a piece of art, it would be by… (laughs) that’s like asking me if I have a favorite child. I’m always buying art and it’s somewhat like an addiction. And part of my job is discovering incredible talent. The most current piece that I bought is by Kobra, a Brazilian street artist. It’s part of a very small handful of canvases that the artist has ever done, so it makes it that much more special. What I find to be so incredible [about artists like Kobra] is that they can work on a really large scale and then they can transition into a smaller scale. That’s why we opened the Goldman Global Arts Gallery—to be able to provide artwork in the genre of street art to collectors.

A passion of mine that few people know about is… it’s not that people don’t know—they do—but my passion is my family. It’s really for me what matters most in the world. And maybe what some people might not know about me is that I’ve never been a dog person and we recently got a dog and I’m in love with my dog! He’s a Golden Doodle, and his name is Csonka, like the (retired) football player Larry Csonka. I live in a household of four men, so there’s a lot of sports talk in my house. But we’re all actually big-time football fans. I’m also one of the co-chairs of the Super Bowl host committee; the Super Bowl is coming to Miami in 2020.

The one trip I’ve taken that I would love to do again… safari in Africa. We were there two years ago, in Tanzania. It was absolutely life-changing. We did it with our kids and we can’t wait to go back, all of us, and explore more of that magnificent continent. It was breathtaking.

The restaurant in my hometown that I would love to take a visitor to is… Joey’s, which is one of our [Goldman Properties’] restaurants. It’s one of the best Italian restaurants in town, and it’s part of the Wynwood Walls experience—you go sit outside in the garden at Joey’s, have an amazing pizza or pasta and then you go for a walk in the Wynwood Walls. It’s a perfect afternoon.

The thing that gets me up in the morning is… the opportunity to make a difference every day. On a recent weekend, my family and I volunteered at Style Saves, an organization started by friends of mine, David and Isabela Grutman. It provides school supplies, backpacks, haircuts, and uniforms to thousands of kids in Florida.

If I could have a drink with anybody, anywhere, it would be… with my dad, for sure. I miss talking to him, and I miss hearing about his wild and wonderful ideas. We would have the drink some place big and beautiful, whether it’s on a mountaintop or on the beach, looking at the water. Nature is a form of art—he and my mom taught me to look at things that way, with optimism and gratitude and wonder. He taught me to look at the world with wonder, so we’d have to find a really wonderful place to have our drink. I don’t drink, so I’d have something super healthy and sweet, like watermelon juice. And he’d have a glass of Scotch.
description: Miami’s Wynwood neighborhood, her juicer, and Harvard Business School case studies for light reading
